title-group.article-title: 1,3-Dioxepine and spiropyran derivatives of viomellein and other dimeric naphthopyranones from cultures of Aspergillus elegans KUFA0015 and their antibacterial activity

1,3-Dioxepine and spiropyran derivatives of viomellein and other dimeric naphthopyranones from cultures of
Aspergillus elegans
KUFA0015 and their antibacterial activity

A R T I C L E I N F O

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p:
Aspergillus elegans
KUFA0015
Marine sponge-associated fungus
Naphthopyranone derivatives
Ochratoxins
Antibacterial activity
A B S T R A C T

Two undescribed viomellein derivatives, xanthoelegansin and spiroxanthoelegansin, were isolated together with clavatol, sitosteanone, vioxanthin, xanthomegnin, viomellein, rubrosulphin, rubrosulphin diacetate, viopurpurin, ochratoxin A, ochratoxin A methyl ester, ochratoxin B and ochratoxin β, from cultures of the marine sponge-associated fungus
Aspergillus elegans
KUFA0015. The structures of the undescribed compounds were established based on an extensive analysis of 1D and 2D NMR spectra as well as HRMS data. The structure of xanthoelegansin and the absolute configuration of its stereogenic carbons were confirmed by X-ray analysis. The change in conformation of xanthoelegansin was interpreted using quantum mechanical theoretical calculation data in combination with the observation of the change of the proton signals of the 1,3-dioxepine ring in 1HNMR spectra at varying temperatures. The mechanisms of the formation of xanthoelegansin and spiroxanthoelegansin from viomellein were proposed. Clavatol, sitosteanone, vioxanthin, xanthomegnin, viomellein, xanthoelegansin, rubrosulphin, rubrosulphin diacetate, ochratoxin A, ochratoxin A methyl ester, ochratoxin B and ochratoxin β were assayed for their antibacterial activity against reference strains and multidrug-resistant isolates from the environment. The tested compounds were also evaluated for their capacity to inhibit biofilm formation in the reference strains.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: * Corresponding author. ICBAS -Instituto de Ciˆencias Biom´edicas Abel Salazar, Rua de Jorge Viterbo Ferreira, 228, 4050-313, Porto , Portugal .

Pereira), lgales@ibmc.up.pt (L. Gales ), joanafreitasdasilva@gmail.com (J. Freitas-Silva), pmcosta@icbas.up.p (P.M. Costa), scm11@leicester.ac.th (S. Mistry), artur.silva@ua.pt (A.M.S. Silva), ankijjoa@icbas.up.pt (A. Kijjoa).

Inspired by several structurally unique and biologically interesting specialised metabolites isolated from
Aspergillus similanensis
sp. nov.
KUFA0013 (
,
) and
A. candidus
KUFA0062 (
) during our investigation to discover bioactive compounds from marine-derived fungi from the Gulf of Thailand and the Andaman Sea, combined with a previous report on isolation of bioactive phenylalanine derivatives and cytochalasins from a marine coral-derived
A. elegans
ZJ-2008010 (
) and the isolation of the antibacterial compound, (+)- epi -epoformin, from the algicolous fungus
A. elegans
SweF9 (
), we embarked on examining specialised metabolites from the cultures of a collection of
A. elegans
KUFA0015 which was isolated from the marine sponge
Monanchora unguiculata ,
collected from the Gulf of Thailand .

Fractionation of the ethyl acetate crude extract of the cultures of
A. elegans
KUFA0015 by column chromatography, followed by purification by preparative TLC, Sephadex LH-20 column and crystallization, furnished the undescribed viomellein derivatives 6 and 7 , together with the previously reported clavatol ( 1 ), sitosteanone ( 2 ), vioxanthin ( 3 ), xanthomegnin ( 4 ), viomellein ( 5 ), rubrosulphin ( 8a ), rubrosulphin diacetate ( 8b ), viopurpurin ( 8c ), ochratoxin A ( 9a ), ochratoxin A methyl ester ( 9b ), ochratoxin B ( 9c ) and ochratoxin β ( 10 ) ( Fig. 1 ). The structures of the undescribed 6 and 7 were established based on an extensive analysis of 1D and 2D NMR as well as HRMS data. In the case of 6 , its structure and absolute configuration of its stereogenic carbons were confirmed by X-ray analysis. Moreover, its conformation change was interpreted using quantum mechanical theoretical calculation data in combination with the observation of the change of the proton signals of the 1,3-dioxepine ring in 1 HNMR spectra at varying temperatures. The identity of the known compounds were elucidated by analysis of their 1D and 2D NMR , HRMS and X-ray analysis as well as by comparison of their 1 H and 13 C data with those described in the literature. In the case of 3 and 5 , the 13 C NMR data were used to distinguish between their atropisomers. Compounds 1–6 , 9a , 9b and 9c were assayed for their antibacterial activity against three reference bacterial strains consisting of two Gram-positive (
Staphylococcus aureus
ATCC 29213 and
Enterococcus faecalis
ATCC29212) and one Gram-negative bacteria (
Escherichia coli
ATCC25922), two multidrug-resistant isolates from the environment ( MRSA
S. aureus
66/1 and VRE
E. faecalis
B3/101) and the clinical isolate ESBL
E. coli
SA/2. Some of the isolated compounds were also investigated for their capacity to inhibit biofilm formation in the three reference strains.

sec.title: 2. Results and discussion
sec.p:
Compound 3 was identified as vioxanthin based on its (+)-HRESIMS m/z at 547.1606 [M+ H] + (calculated for C 30 H 27 O 10 , 547.1604) (Figure S72), the 1 H and 13 C NMR data and 2D NMR correlations ( Table 1 and Figures S5-S 9) (
). Since 3 was obtained as a suitable crystal, the X-ray analysis was carried out. The ORTEP view of 3 ( Fig. 2 ) shows clearly that the absolute configuration of both C-3 and C-3’ is R . Moreover, the ORTEP view of 3 ( Fig. 2 ) also shows that 3 exists as M, R, R -atropisomer in a crystalline form.

However, the 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra ( Table 1 , Figures S5 and S 6 ) of 3 displayed the signals of OH-9 and OH-10 as two pairs of doublets of very close chemical shift values at δH 9.708 ( J = 1.1 Hz)/9.701 ( J = 1.1 Hz), and at δH 13.806 ( J = 1.1 Hz)/13.803 ( J = 1.1 Hz), respectively, whereas OMe-7 also appeared as two singlets at δH 3.845 and 3.843, indicating that 3 existed in equilibrium of two atropisomers in a solution. This was supported by the fact that C-1/C-1 ′ appear as two signals at δC 171.60 and 171.56. According to
, the 1 H NMR spectra of P, R, R -vioxanthin and M, R, R -vioxanthin were identical whereas the 13 C NMR spectra exhibited small differences in chemical shift values for the carbonyl carbon of the pyranone ring (C-1 and C-1 ′ ) being δC 171.57 in P, R, R - and δC 171.61 in M, R, R -atropisomers, respectively. As the 13 C NMR spectrum of 3 ( Figure S6 ) exhibited two signals of C-1/C-1’ at δC 171.56 and 171.60, respectively, it was suggested that 3 exists in equilibrium of two atropisomers in the CDCl 3 solution ( Fig. 3 ).

The 13 C NMR data ( Table 3S and Figure S11) of 4 were compatible with those reported for xanthomegnin by
. However, contrary to the 15 carbon signals reported by Hofel ¨and Roser ¨ (1978), the 13 C NMR spectrum of 4 , obtained in CDCl 3 at 75 MHz ( Table 3S , Figure S11), exhibited pairs of signals, with close chemical shift values, of some carbons, i. e. for C-3/C-3 ′ , C-4/C-4 ′ , C-4a/C-4’a, C-5a/C-5’a, C-6/C-6 ′ , C-8/C-8’a, C-9/C-9’a, C-10/C-10’a, C-10a/C-10’a and Me-3/Me-3’. Similarly, the 1 H NMR spectrum in CDCl 3 at 300 MHz ( Table 3S ; Figure S10) exhibited a pair of singlets at δH 13. 17 (lower intensity) and 13.19 (higher intensity) of the hydroxyl group at C-10, a pair of singlets at δH 4.164 (higher intensity) and 4.157 (lower intensity) for the methoxyl group, and a pair of methyl doublets at δH 1.55 ( J = 6.2 Hz, lower intensity) and 1.57 ( J = 6.2 Hz, higher intensity). Since xanthomegnin is a dimer of two identical monomers, these pairs of 1 H and 13 C signals also suggested that it exists as a mixture of M and P atropisomers in a solution. However, it is not possible to identify which proton and carbon signals belong to the P or M isomers.

Compound 5 was identified as viomellein based on the analysis of its 1D and 2D NMR spectra ( Table 3 , Figures S15-S19) and its (+)-HRESIMS m/z 561.1389 (M + H) + (calcd for C 30 H 25 O 11 , 561.1397)(Figure S73). Instead of showing only one signal for each carbon as previously reported by
, the 13 C NMR spectrum, obtained in CDCl 3 at 75 MHz ( Table 2 , Figure S16), exhibited pairs of signals for a majority of carbons. Similarly, the 1 H NMR spectrum ( Table 2 , Figure S15) showed a pair of signals for Me-3, Me-3 ′ , OMe-7 ′ , OH-9, OH-10 and OH-10’. This implies that 5 also exists in equilibrium of P and M atropisomers in CDCl 3 solution. However, in a crystalline form, it exists only as M atropisomer as shown in the ORTEP diagram in Fig. 4 .

Compound 6 was isolated as a red crystal (mp. 265–267 ◦ C), and its molecular formula C 30 H 22 O 11 was established based on the (+)-HRESIMS m/z 559.1235 (M + H) + (calculated for C 30 H 23 O 11 , 559.1240)(Figure S74), indicating twenty degrees of unsaturation. The IR spectrum showed absorption bands for hydroxyl ( 3445 cm 1 ), conjugated ketone carbonyl (1732, 1717 cm 1 ), olefin ( 1649 cm 1 ), aromatic (1559, 1541 cm 1 ) and ether ( 1230 cm 1 ) groups. The general features of the 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra of 6 ( Table 3 , Figures S20 and S21) resembled those of 5 with some small differences. The 1 H NMR spectrum in CDCl 3 ( Table 3 , Figure S20) displayed two pairs of singlets of hydrogen-bonded hydroxyls at δH 13.034 / 13.017 and δH 12.962 / 12.933 , three singlets of aromatic protons at δH 7.56, 6.98 and 6.95, three doublets (all integrated for two protons) from higher to lower intensity at δH 6.08 ( J = 4.6 Hz), 6.02 ( J = 4.6 Hz) and 5.98 ( J = 4.6 Hz), two multiplets at δH 4.78 (1H) and 4.71 (1H), a methoxyl singlet at δH 3.89 (3H), two overlapped multiplets at δH 2.98 and 3.05 (4H), and two methyl doublets at δH 1.56 ( J = 6.0 Hz) and 1.57 ( J = 6.0 Hz), respectively. The 13 C NMR spectrum ( Table 3 , Figure S21) displayed several pairs of signals which, in combination with DEPTs and HSQC (Figure S24) spectra, can be categorized as two ketone carbonyls at δC 186.0 (C-9 ′ ) and 179.0 (C-6 ′ ), conjugated ester carbonyls at δC 170.99/ 170.88 (C-1), 163.4 (C-1 ′ ), five non-protonated oxygen-bearing sp 2 at δC 163.07/162.98 (C-10), 162.58/162.52 (C-10 ′ ),158.61/158.57 (C-7), 157.49/157.41 (C-9), 153.42/153.31 (C-7 ′ ), eleven non-protonated sp 2 at δC 147.76/147.54 (C-4’a), 141.12/141.08 (C-5a), 136.00/135.87 (C- 4a), 134.82/134.51 (C-5’a), 129.33/129.18 (C-8 ′ ), 116.3 (C-10’a), 116.2 (C-9’a), 115.89/115.81 (C-8), 112.0 (C-9a), 101.8 (C-10a), three protonated sp 2 at δC 116.6 (C-5 ′ ), 115.36/115.27 (C-5), 104.15/104.11 (C-6), two oxymethine sp 3 at δC 75.99/75.91 (C-3) and 74.74/74.64 (C- 3 ′ ), one oxymethylene sp 3 at δC 105.41/105.27 (C-11), two methylene sp 3 at δC 35.1 (C-4) and 36.12/35.86 (C-4 ′ ), and two methyl carbons at δC 20.65/20.60 (Me-3) and 20.79 (Me-3 ′ ). The obvious difference between the structures of 5 and 6 is the presence of two methoxy and three phenolic hydroxyl groups in the former and one methoxy and two phenolic hydroxyl groups, in addition to the dioxymethylene group ( δC 105.41/105.27; δH 6.08, d, J = 4.6 Hz) in the latter. Moreover, the presence of another two doublets at δH 6.02 ( J = 4.6 Hz) and δH 5.98 ( J = 4.6 Hz) in 6 also was unprecedented in the naphthopyranone fungal pigments. The HMBC spectrum ( Table 3 , Figure S25) exhibited correlations from the singlet at δH 6.95 (H-6) and the singlet at δH 3.89 (OMe- 7) to the carbon signals at δH 158.61/158.57 (C-7) whereas the doublet at δH 6.08 ( J = 4.6 Hz) showed cross peaks to C-7 and the carbons at δC 157.49/157.41 (C-9). The NOESY spectrum (Figure S23) also showed correlation from H-6 to OMe-7. Taking the proton and carbon chemical shift values of the methylene group and the HMBC correlations into consideration, a dioxymethylene bridge was placed between C-7 ′ and C- 9.

Since the NMR spectra of 6 show signal doubling on most of its nuclei (Figures S20, S21, S26, S31), it was hypothesized that this was due to the presence of slow conformational equilibria at the NMR time scale. Notably, the H-11 diastereotopic geminal protons exhibit a somewhat unexpected signal pattern that was explained by proposing slow exchange between the two conformations of the central ring. Experimental evidence for the exchange process came from 1 H NMR spectra of 6 , in DMSO ‑d 6 , at varying temperatures (Figures S26-S30). As shown in Fig. 6 for H 2 -11, we observed that all doubled signals progressively broaden and begin to get closer as the temperature is increased, indicating the presence of slow exchange between conformations that progresses to a faster exchange regime with temperature.

Quantum mechanical theoretical data were also calculated in an attempt to obtain further explanations for the experimental NMR observations and further insight on the phenomenon. A representative collection (2 kcal/mole Gibbs energy window, 298 K) of the most stable conformational models of 6 ( R , R -configuration) was used to predict the relative abundance of its conformers and the resulting 1 H NMR spectrum. It was found that the most stable conformers of 6 can be organized in two groups, G1 and G2, corresponding to the two conformations of the central ring. These two conformational groups are well represented by the leftmost and rightmost models in Fig. 6 , where the transition state (TS) model for G1/G2 conversion is presented in the middle.

The calculated populations are about 59% for the conformational group G1 and 41% for the conformational group G2. This allows the assignment of H-11 signals to G1 and G2 groups since the integral of the doublet at ca. 6.00 ppm (labeled G1/ Hb , 54%) is slightly bigger than the integral of the doublet at ca. 5.95 ppm (labeled G2/ Ha , 46%), respectively. The simulated NMR spectrum assisted in assigning Ha and Hb to the NMR signals because the calculated chemical shift value of the proton that is spatially nearer the quinone ring (top parts of the models in Fig. 7 ) is consistently slightly higher than that calculated for its geminal neighbor, hence the assignments are presented in Fig. 7 .

The calculated Gibbs energy for the transition state (TS) model is higher than average G1’s by 21.5 kcal/mole and average G2’s by about 21.3 kcal/mole. These activation energies enable to calculate the average first order rate constants
kG 1
> G
2
and
kG 2
> G
1
at 298 K for the conversion between conformations G1 and G2. These were used to calculate the theoretical average exchange rate
kexchange
=
kG 1
> G
2
+
kG 2
> G
1
= 0.006 Hz. This value is much smaller than the frequency difference between Ha signals ( ΔG1/Ha and G2/Ha ~30 Hz) and between Hb signals ( ΔG1/Hb and G2/Hb ~ 50 Hz) which clearly explains why 6 exhibits slow exchange in the NMR spectra at room temperature. Theoretical and experimental data (extrapolating from spectra in Fig. 6 ) suggest that temperature would probably have to be raised above 100 ◦ C to start observing fast exchange (no signal doubling) in the NMR spectra. The predicted first order half-life for G1/G2 conversion is ln(2)
/
kexchange
= 115 s, which means effective conformational equilibrium at room temperature is expected to be reached within 15 min if starting from only one of the central ring conformations, G1 or G2.

The experimental electronic circular dichroism (ECD) spectrum of 6 was measured but no signals were detected. This is probably the case of extremely low absorption differences between left and right polarized light since the concentration values and the acquisition parameters used for 6 typically give strong ECD spectra for other chiral organic molecules.

Compound 6 can be hypothesized to be derived from viomellein ( 5 ) by a mechanism analogous to the formation of methylenedioxy group of the benzene ring of many natural products (
) as shown in Scheme 1 . Since the X-ray analysis of viomellein ( 5 ) revealed that the predominant atropisomer is M, R, R ( Fig. 5 ), a nucleophilic attack of the oxymethylidene group, formed by oxidation at the methoxy group on C-7 ′ , by the phenolic hydroxyl group on C-9 resulted in a formation of a 1,3-dioxepine ring, connecting the two monomers through C-8/C-8 ′ and C-9/C-7’. Since 6 has never been reported previously, it was named xanthoelegansin. Compound 6 is the first analogue of naphthopyranone dimers possessing a 1,3-dioxepine ring.

Compound 7 was isolated as a colorless viscous mass and its molecular formula C 30 H 22 O 11 was established based on the (+)-HRESIMS m/z 559.1255 [M+ H] + (calculated for C 30 H 22 O 11 , 559.1240) (Figure S75), indicating 20 degrees of unsaturation. The IR spectrum showed absorption bands for hydroxyl ( 3445 cm 1 ), conjugated ketone carbonyl ( 1685 cm 1 ), olefin ( 1606 cm 1 ), aromatic ( 1555 cm 1 ) and ether ( 1276 cm 1 ) groups. The general features of the 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra of 7 ( Table 4 , Figures S32 and S33) resemble those of 6. The 1 H NMR spectrum, at 500 MHz, of 7 ( Table 4 , Figure S32) displayed a broad singlet at δH 13.07 and a pair of singlets at δH 12.760 / 12.752 (one proton), characteristic of hydrogen-bonded phenolic groups, three singlets of aromatic protons at δH 7.50, 6.58 and 5.82, two pairs of doublets at δH , d ( J = 9.3 Hz), d ( J = 9.3 Hz) and, d ( J = 9.3 Hz), d ( J = 9.3 Hz), a multiplet of two protons at δH 4.68, a pair of singlets of a methoxy group at δH 3.820 / 3.817 , two multiplets at δH 3.03 (2H) and 2.98 (2H), and two methyl doublets at δH 1.54 ( J = 6.2 Hz) and 1.55 ( J = 6.2 Hz). Like 6 , the 13 C NMR of 7 ( Table 4 , Figure S33) showed several pairs of carbon signals, with different intensity, indicating the presence of two major conformers. In conjunction with DEPT, HSQC (Figure S35) and HMBC (Figure S36) spectra, the 13 C NMR spectrum of 7 exhibited, besides signals of a conjugated ketone carbonyl at δC 197.0 (only observed in the HMBC spectrum), two carbonyls of a 1,4-naphthoquinone at δC 183.5 and δC 176.59/176.53, conjugated lactone carbonyls at δC 161.85/ 161.79, four oxygen-bearing sp 2 carbons at δC 145.7, 160.84/160.79, 164.93/164.88 and 162.77/162.70, three protonated sp 2 carbons at δC 97.9, 116.9 and 117.0, eight non-protonated sp 2 carbons at δC 109.05/ 109.02, 111.38/111.25, 115.56/115.49, 117.58/117.76, 127.94/ 127.87, 135.52/135.44, 149.5, 147.71/147.57, two oxygenated methine sp 3 at δC 74.2 and 74.76/74.68, one oxygenated methylene sp 3 at δC 82.96/82.92, two methylene sp 3 at δC 36.07 and 35.94/35.80 and two methyl carbons at δC 20.6 and 20.7. That 7 contains the same 6- methyl-2-pyrano-1,4-naphthoquinone portion as that of 5 and 6 was substantiated by the presence of C-6’ ( δC 176.59/176.53) and C-9’ ( δC 183.5), CH-5’ ( δH 7.50/ δC 117.0), OH-10’ ( δH 12.760 / 12.752 , s) as well as CH-3’ ( δC 74.76/74.68; δH 4.68, m), CH 2 -4’ ( δC 35.94/35.80; δH 3.03, m), CH 3 -3’ ( δC 20.7/ δH 1.55, d, J = 6.2 Hz). This was corroborated by HMBC correlations ( Table 4 , Fig. 8 and S36) from H-5 ′ to C-4 ′ , 6 ′ and the carbon signals at δC 115.56/115.49 (C-9’a) and 117.58/117.76 (C-10’a), and from OH-10 ′ to C-9’a, C-10’a, and the carbon signals at δC 162.77/ 162.70 (C-10 ′ ). That another portion of the molecule contains a 6,7- disubstituted 8-hydroxyisochromone moiety was corroborated by the presence of a singlet of the aromatic proton at δH 6.58 (H-5/ δC 116.9), a singlet of the hydrogen-bonded phenolic hydroxyl at δH 13.07 (OH-10), a multiplet of an oxymethine proton at δH 4.68 (H-3/ δC 74.2), a multiplet of methylene protons at δH 2.98 (H-4/ δC 36.07) and a methyl doublet at δH 1.54, J = 6.2 Hz (Me-3/ δC 20.6). This was confirmed by HMBC correlations ( Table 4 , Fig. 8 and S36) from H-5 to C-4 and the carbon signals at δC 111.38/111.25 (C-9a) and 109.05/109.02 (C-10a), as well as from Me-3 to C-3. That the 6,7-disubstituted 8-hydroxyisochromone moiety was fused with the 3-methoxy-3-cyclohexenone ring, at C-5a and C-9a, was substantiated by HMBC correlations ( Table 4 , Fig. 8 and S36) from the singlet at δH 5.82 (H-6/ δC 97.9) to C-5, C-9a, and the signals the oxygenated sp 2 carbon at δC 160.84/160.79 (C- 7) and the quaternary sp 3 carbon at δC 61.29/61.21, from the methyl singlets at δH 3.820 / 3.817 (OMe-7, δC 56.40/56.38) to C-7, from H-5 to C-6. That the 3-methoxy-3-cyclohexenone ring was connected to the 6- methyl-2-pyrano-1,4-naphthoquinone portion by a spiropyran ring through C-8 to C-8 ′ , C-8 to C-11 and C-11 to C-7 ′ , via an ether bridge, was corroborated by the HMBC correlations from the two pairs of doublets at δH 5.07/5.06, and 4.97/4.96 (H 2 -11/ δC 82.96/82.92) to C-7, C-8, the carbonyl carbon at δC 197.0 (C-9) and the carbon signal at δC 127.94/127.87 (C-8 ′ ). Therefore, the planar structure of 7 was proposed as shown in Fig. 8 . Since 7 is a viscous liquid, it was not possible to determine the absolute configuration of C-8 by X-ray crystallography.

Compound 7 can be hypothesized to be derived from viomellein ( 5 ) by a mechanism similar to that proposed for the formation of the 1,3- dioxepine ring in 6 . Oxidation of the methoxy group on C-7 ′ of viomellein ( 5 ), followed by nucleophilic addition by a carbanion at C-8, formed by keto-enol tautomerization, of the oxymethylidene group resulted in a formation of the spiropyran ring as shown in Scheme 2 . Based on these assumptions, a nucleophilc attack of the oxymethylidene group on C-7’ by the C-8 carbanion would generate the S configuration on C-6. Literature search revealed that 7 has never been previously isolated, thus it was named spiroxanthoelegansin.
a Observed by HMBC correlation.

The 1 H, 13 C NMR data, COSY, HSQC and HMBC correlations (Table S11; Figures S67-S71) of 10 allowed to identify it as ochratoxin β. Although ochratoxin β was previously obtained by synthesis as well as by hydrolysis of ochratoxin B (
), there is no report of its 1 H, 13 C NMR and other physical data in any literature. Recently,
, in their work on genome sequencing of
A. ochraceus
to study ochratoxin A biosynthetic pathway, have hypothesized that ochratoxin β is produced by 7-methylmellein by cytochrome P450 monooxygenase (OtaC). Combination of ochratoxin β with L-β- phenylalanine, catalyzed by a nonribosomal peptide synthetase (OtaB), resulted in a formation of ochratoxin B. However, it is not possible to prove if ochratoxin β ( 10 ), isolated in this work, was produced by the fungus or by hydrolysis of ochratoxin B ( 9c ) which was co-isolated in this work. Based on the biogenetic consideration, the absolute configuration of C-3 of 10 must be the same as that of 8c , 8a and 8b .

The antimicrobial activity of 1–10 against Gram-negative and Gram-positive bacteria was evaluated by a disc diffusion method as well as by determination of their minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) and minimum bactericidal concentration (MBC) against several reference strains as well as environmental and clinical multidrug-resistant isolates. In the disc diffusion assay, there was a halo of growth inhibition for all Gram-positive strains exposed to 3 , 4, 5 and 9b ( Table 5 ), and it was also possible to determine MIC for these compounds ( Table 5 ). Compound 3 showed a very potent activity against all Gram-positive strains tested, with MIC values of 1–2 μg/mL for
Enterococcus faecalis
ATCC 29212 and 1 μg/mL for vancomycin-resistant
E. faecalis
(VRE) B3/101, whereas its MIC values for
Staphylococcus aureus
ATCC 29213 and methicillin-resistant
S. aureus
(MRSA) 66/1 were 2 μg/mL and 0.5 μg/mL, respectively.

Their MBC values were equal to or two-fold higher than their MIC values, indicating a bactericidal effect. Compound 5 also exhibited a bactericidal effect, and its MIC values were 4–8 μg/mL for
S. aureus
ATCC 29213, 2 μg/mL for
S. aureus
66/1, and 8 μg/mL for
E. faecalis
ATCC 29212; however, it was not possible to determine its MIC for
E. faecalis
B3/10, as it is higher than 16 μg/mL, the highest concentration that could be essayed in order to keep in-test concentrations of DMSO below 1%. Compound 7 displayed MIC values between 8 and 16 μg/mL for all Gram-positive strains, however, it was not possible to determine its MBC values in the range of concentrations tested (higher than 64 μg/mL), suggesting that this compound has a bacteriostatic effect. The MIC values for 4 were between 16 and 32 μg/mL for all Gram-positive strains, however, its MBC values could not be determined since the highest concentration tested was 32 μg/mL to keep in-test concentrations of DMSO below 1%. None of the compounds were active against Gram-negative bacteria.

The ability of 1–10 to prevent biofilm formation was evaluated on all three reference strains by measuring a total biomass. Compounds that showed a statistically significant reduction (one sample t -test) of biofilm formation are shown in Table 6 . For 3 , 4 , 5 and 9b , concentrations ranging from 2 x MIC to ¼ MIC were tested against
E. faecalis
ATCC 29212 and
S. aureus
ATCC 29213, while keeping in-test concentrations of DMSO below 1%. For all others, since it was not possible to determine their MIC values, the highest concentration tested in previous assays was assessed. Despite no antibacterial activity was shown in the range of concentrations tested, 1 , 2 and 10 were able to significantly inhibit biofilm formation of
E. coli
ATCC 25922 whereas 10 also inhibited biofilm production by
S. aureus
ATCC 29213. Similarly, 8b showed an inhibition of biofilm formation by
E. faecalis
ATCC 29212. Interestingly, the compounds possessing antibacterial activity,
i. e. 3
, 4 , 5 and 9b , almost completely inhibited biofilm formation by
E. faecalis
and
S. aureus
reference strains at MIC and 2xMIC. Moreover, 4 and 9b also displayed significant inhibition at ½ MIC.

In terms of antibacterial activity, 3 is the most promising compound showing a potent activity against all Gram-positive reference and multidrug-resistant strains tested. These results call for a more in-depth study of this compound including the mechanisms underlying its antibacterial activity.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: MIC, Minimum Inhibitory Concentration; MBC, Minimum Bactericidal Concentration; (), no inhibition halo.

sec.title: 3. Experimental section
sec.p: 3.1. General experimental procedures

sec.title: 3.2. Fungal material
sec.p:
The fungus was isolated from the marine sponge
Monanchora unguiculata
which was collected, by scuba diving at a depth of 5–10 m , from the coral reef at the Kram Island (
12 ◦ 34 ′ 24.6138 ′′ N
,
100 ◦ 55 ′ 55.3902 ′′ E
), in the Gulf of Thailand , Chonburi Province in April 2016 . The sponge was washed with 0.01% sodium hypochlorite solution for 1 min, followed by sterilized seawater for three times and then dried on a sterile filter paper under sterile aseptic condition. The sponge was then cut into small pieces ( ca. 5 mm × 5 mm ) and placed on a Petri dish containing 15 mL malt extract agar (MEA) with 70% seawater, and incubated at room temperature for 7 days. The hyphal tips emerging from sponge pieces were individually transferred onto MEA slants and maintained as pure cultures at Department of Plant Pathology, Faculty of Agriculture, Kasetsart University in Bangkok , Thailand , for further identification. The fungal strain KUFA0015 was identified as
Aspergillus elegans
, based on morphological characteristics and microscopic characteristics including size, shape, and ornamentation of spores under light microscopes. This identification was confirmed by molecular techniques using internal transcribed spacer (ITS) primers. DNA was extracted from young mycelia following a modified
. PCR reactions were conducted on Thermal Cycler and the amplification process consisted of initial denaturation at 95 ◦ C for 5 min, 34 cycles at 95 ◦ C for 1 min (denaturation), at 55 ◦ C for 1 min (annealing) and at 72 ◦ C for 1.5 min (extension), followed by final extension at 72 ◦ C for 10 min. PCR products were examined by agarose gel electrophoresis (1% agarose with 1x Tris-Borate-EDTA (TBE) buffer) and visualized under UV light after staining with ethidium bromide. DNA sequencing analyses were performed using dideoxyribonucleotide chain termination method (
) by Macrogen Inc. ( Seoul , South Korea ). The DNA sequences were edited using the FinchTV software (version 1.4, Geospiza Inc., Seattle, WA, USA ) and submitted to the BLAST program for alignment and compared to fungal species in the NCBI database (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/). Its gene sequences were deposited in GenBank with accession number KX 431209.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Data are shown as mean ± SD of three independent experiments. One-sample t - test: *
p <
0.05, **
p <
0.01, ***
p <
0.001 significantly different from 100%. MIC, Minimum Inhibitory Concentration.

sec.title: 3.3. Extraction and isolation
sec.p: The fungus was cultured for 1 week at 28 ◦ C in five Petri dishes (i.d. 90 mm ) containing 20 mL of potato dextrose agar per dish. The mycelial plugs ( 5 mm in diameter) were transferred to two 500 mL Erlenmeyer flasks containing 200 mL of potato dextrose broth, and incubated on a rotary shaker at 120 rpm at 28 ◦ C for one week. Fifty 1000 mL Erlenmeyer flasks, each containing 300 g of cooked rice, were autoclaved at 121 ◦ C for 15 min. After cooling to room temperature, 20 mL of a mycelial suspension of the fungus was inoculated per flask and incubated at 28 ◦ C for 30 days, after which 500 mL of EtOAc was added to each flask of the moldy rice and macerated for 7 days, and then filtered with Whatman No. 1 filter paper (GE Healthcare UK Limited, Buckinghamshire , UK ). The EtOAc solutions were combined and concentrated under reduced pressure to yield 105.8 g of crude EtOAc extract which was dissolved in 500 mL of CHCl 3 and then filtered with Whatman No. 1 filter paper was dissolved in 500 mL of CHCl 3 and then filtered with Whatman No. 1 filter paper. The CHCl 3 solution was then washed with H 2 O (3 × 500 mL) and dried with anhydrous Na 2 SO 4 , filtered and evaporated under reduced pressure to give 87.1 g of crude CHCl 3 extract. The crude CHCl 3 extract ( 49 g ) was applied on a column of silica gel ( 285 g ), and eluted with mixtures of petrol-CHCl 3 and CHCl 3 –Me 2 CO, wherein 250 mL fractions (Frs) were collected as follow: Frs 1–161 (petrol-CHCl 3 , 1:1), 162–218 (petrol-CHCl 3 , 3:7), 219–298 (petrol-CHCl 3 , 1:9), 299–520 (CHCl 3 ). 521–719 (CHCl 3 : Me 2 CO, 9:1), 720–793 (CHCl 3 : Me 2 CO, 7:3). Frs 56–67 were combined ( 657 mg ), applied on a Sephadex LH-20 column ( 5 g ) and eluted with a mixture of MeOH: CHCl 3 (4:1), wherein 20 subfractions (Sfrs) of 2 mL were collected. Sfrs 5–15 were combined and purified by TLC (Silica gel G 254 , CHCl 3 : Petrol: EtOAc: HCO 2 H, 90:5:5:0.1) to give 7.3 mg of 1 . Frs 68–80 were combined (401.0 mg) and purified by TLC (Silica gel G 254 , CHCl 3 : Petrol: EtOAc: HCO 2 H, 90: 5: 5: 0.1) to give 8.9 mg of 1 , and 21.1 mg of 2 . Frs 81–113 were combined ( 441.6 mg ) and applied on a Sephadex LH-20 column and eluted with a mixture of CHCl 3 : MeOH (1:1), wherein 15 sfrs of 3 mL were collected. Sfrs 5–10 were combined and purified by TLC (Silica gel G 254 , CHCl 3 : Petrol: EtOAc: HCO 2 H, 90: 5: 5: 0.1) to give additional 6.0 mg of 1 . Frs 328–353 were combined ( 368.5 mg ) and precipitated in CHCl 3 to give 13.0 mg of 3 , and a mother liquor. The mother liquor of frs 328–353 was combined with frs 288–327 ( 428.7 mg ) and frs 354–399 ( 368.8 mg ) to give combined frs 288–399 ( 1.14 g ) which were applied on a silica gel ( 20 g ) column and eluted with mixtures of petrol-CHCl 3 and CHCl 3 –Me 2 CO, wherein 100 mL sfrs were collected as follows: sfrs 1–18 (petrol:CHCl 3 , 1:1), 19–46 (petrol:CHCl 3 , 3:7), 47–53 (petrol:CHCl 3 , 1:9), 54–123 (CHCl 3 ), 124–140 (CHCl 3 : Me 2 CO, 9:1) and 141–148 (CHCl 3 : Me 2 CO, 7:3). Sfrs 51–107 were combined ( 202.6 mg ) and purified by TLC (Silica gel G 254 , CHCl 3 : MeOH: HCO 2 H, 97:3:0.1) to give additional 17.3 mg of 3 . Frs 400–525 were combined ( 3.41 g ) and crystallized in MeOH to give 26.5 mg of 6 . Fr. 526 (5.0 g) was applied on a Sephadex LH-20 ( 10 g ) column and eluted with MeOH, wherein 30 sfrs of 5 mL were collected. Sfrs 7–10 were combined to give 20 mg of 4 . Sfrs 11–30 were combined ( 3.9 g ) and applied on a silica gel ( 45 g ) column and eluted with petrol-CHCl 3 , CHCl 3 , CHCl 3 –Me 2 CO and MeOH, wherein 100 mL sfrs were collected as follows: sfrs 1–35 (petrol:CHCl 3 , 1:1), 36–80 (petrol:CHCl 3 , 3:7), 81–109 (petrol:CHCl 3 , 1:9), 110–167 (CHCl 3 ), 168–200 (CHCl 3 : Me 2 CO, 9:1), 201–245 (CHCl 3 : Me 2 CO, 7:3). Sfrs 159–184 were combined ( 336.4 mg ) and purified by TLC (Silica gel G 254 , CHCl 3 : MeOH: HCO 2 H, 97:3:0.1) to give additional 17.6 mg of 4 . Sfrs 233–239 were combined ( 119.2 mg ) and purified by TLC (Silica gel G 254 , CHCl 3 : MeOH: HCO 2 H, 97: 3: 0.1) to give 10.2 mg of 9a . Sfr 297 (469.0 mg) was applied on a Sephadex LH-20 ( 10 g ) column and eluted with MeOH to give additional 9.1 mg of 9a and 11.2 mg of 9b . Frs 527–532 were combined ( 4.90 g ) and applied on a Sephadex LH-20 column ( 20 g ) and eluted with a mixture of CHCl 3 : MeOH (1:1), wherein 130 of 2 mL sfrs were collected. Sfrs 66–91 were combined ( 0.9 g ), applied on a Sephadex LH-20 column ( 20 g ) and eluted with MeOH. The sfrs were combined and purified by TLC (Silica gel G 254 , CHCl 3 : MeOH: HCO 2 H, 97:3:0.1) to give 29.7 mg of 8b and 31.9 of 8a . Sfrs 92–117 were combined ( 960 mg ) and applied on a Sephadex LH-20 column ( 20 g ) and eluted with MeOH to give 21.2 mg of 7 . Sfrs 118–125 were combined ( 1.2 g ) and applied on a silica gel column ( 25 g ) and eluted with petrol-CHCl 3 , CHCl 3 and CHCl 3 –Me 2 CO, wherein 100 mL sub-subfractions (ssfrs) were collected as follows: ssfrs 1–20 (petrol-CHCl 3, 1:1), 21–50 (petrol-CHCl 3, 3:7), 51–70 (petrol-CHCl 3, 1:9), 71–107 (CHCl 3 ), 108–127 CHCl 3 –Me 2 CO, 9:1), 128–153 CHCl 3 –Me 2 CO, 7:3). Ssfrs 112–138 were combined ( 286.3 mg ) and purified by TLC (Silica gel G 254 , CHCl 3 : MeOH: HCO 2 H, 97: 3:0.1) to give additional 10.1 mg of 9b . Ssfrs 139–143 were combined ( 92.1 mg ) and purified by TLC (Silica gel G 254 , CHCl 3 : MeOH: HCO 2 H, 97: 3: 0.1) to give 12.1 mg of 5 . Frs 536–550 were combined ( 3.52 g ) and applied on a silica gel column ( 30 g ) and eluted with petrol-CHCl 3 , CHCl 3 and CHCl 3 –Me 2 CO, wherein 100 mL sfrs were collected as follows: sfrs 1–24 (petrol-CHCl 3, 1:1), 25–66 (petrol-CHCl 3 , 3:7), 67–161 (petrol-CHCl 3, 1:9), 162–255 (CHCl 3 ), 256–360 (CHCl 3 –Me 2 CO, 9:1). Sfrs 48–159 were combined and purified by TLC (Silica gel G 254 , CHCl 3 : petrol: EtOAc, 90: 5: 5) to give 3.4 mg of 9b . Sfrs 223–257 were combined ( 1.19 g ), applied over a column of Sephadex LH-20 ( 20 g ) and eluted with MeOH, wherein 131 ssfrs of 1 mL were collected. Ssfrs 48–129 were combined ( 729.3 mg ) and applied on a column of Sephadex LH-20 ( 20 g ) and eluted with MeOH, wherein 159 frs of 1 mL were collected. Frs 41–71 were combined ( 179.1 mg ) and applied over a column of Sephadex LH-20 ( 10 g ) and eluted with petrol: CHCl 3 : MeOH, 2:2:1, wherein 212 sfrs of 1 mL were collected. Sfrs 63–103 were combined (72.0 mg) and purified by TLC (Silica gel G 254 , CHCl 3 : petrol: EtOAc: Me 2 CO, 80: 5: 10:5) to give 19.0 mg of 4 . Frs 72–159 were combined ( 526.1 mg ) and applied over a column of Sephadex LH-20 ( 10 g ) and eluted with petrol: CHCl 3 : MeOH, 2:2:1, wherein 230 sfrs of 1 mL were collected. Sfr. 230 was crystallized in MeOH to give 1.4 mg of 10 . Ssfrs 130–131 were combined ( 35.8 mg ) and applied over a column of Sephadex LH-20 ( 10 g ) and eluted with MeOH, wherein 122 frs of 1 mL were collected. Frs 113–122 were combined and crystallized in MeOH to give 4.1 mg of 8a . Sfrs 258–259 were combined ( 1.02 g ) and precipitated in MeOH to give 30.2 mg of 9c . The mother liquor was dried and recrystallized in MeOH to give additional 16.6 mg of 9c . The mother liquor was purified by TLC (Silica gel G 254 , CHCl 3 : MeOH: HCO 2 H, 97: 3:0.1) to give 5.9 mg of 8b . Frs 551–562 were combined ( 1.104 g ) and crystallized in MeOH to give 42.1 mg of 9c . The mother liquor (1.0 g) was applied on a Sephadex LH-20 column ( 20 g ) and eluted with MeOH to give additional 17.3 mg of 9c .

sec.title: 3.3.1. Xanthoelegansin (6)
sec.p: Red crystal. Mp. 265–267 ◦ C. [α]23 D + 220 ( c 0.05, MeOH); IR (KBr) ν max 3445, 2961, 2920, 1732, 1717, 1649, 1559, 1541, 1521, 1230, 1220 cm 1 ; For 1 H and 13 C spectroscopic data (CDCl 3 , 500 and 125 MHz), see Table 3 ; (+)-HRESIMS m/z 581.1046 (M + Na) + (calculated for C 30 H 22 O 11 Na, 581.1060) and 559.1235 (M + H) + (calculated for C 30 H 23 O 11 , 559.1240).

sec.p: Yellow viscous mass. [α]23 D + 180 ( c 0.05, CHCl 3 ); IR (KBr) ν max 3445, 2957, 2923, 1685, 1606, 1555, 1276 cm 1 ; For 1 H and 13 C spectroscopic data (CDCl 3 , 500 and 125 MHz), see Table 4 ; (+)-HRESIMS m/z 581.1043 (M + Na) + (calculated for C 30 H 22 O 11 Na, 581.1060) and 559.1223 (M + H) + (calculated for C 30 H 23 O 11 , 559.1240).

sec.title: 3.4. X-ray crystal structures
sec.p:
Single crystals were mounted on cryoloops using paratone. X-ray diffraction data were collected at 290 K with a Gemini PX Ultra equipped with CuKα radiation (λ = 1.54184 Å). The structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97 and refined with SHELXL-97 (
). Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms were either placed at their idealized positions using appropriate HFIX instructions in SHELXL and included in subsequent refinement cycles or were directly found from difference Fourier maps and were refined freely with isotropic displacement parameters.

sec.title: 3.4.1. X-ray crystal structure of 3
sec.p: Crystal was monoclinic, space group C2/ m , cell volume 2496.17(12) Å 3 and unit cell dimensions a = 12.2418(3) Å, b = 9.5581(2) Å and c = 21.7930(6) Å, and β = 101.790(3) ◦ (uncertainties in parentheses). The molecule is formed by two symmetry-related tricyclic structures and there are two of these tricyclic rings belonging to different molecules in the asymmetric unit. The flack x parameter was refined with SHELXL-97 by means of TWIN and BASF to yield 0.0(4). The refinement converged to R (all data) = 6.32% and wR2 (all data) = 12.82%. Full details of the data collection and refinement and tables of atomic coordinates, bond lengths and angles, and torsion angles have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (CCDC, 2032221).

sec.title: 3.4.2. X-ray crystal structure of 5
sec.p: Crystal was monoclinic, space group P 21 / m , cell volume 2569.9(2) Å 3 and unit cell dimensions a = 11.2976(5) Å, b = 10.9113(5) Å and c = 21.1026(10) Å, and β = 98.913(5) ◦ . There are two molecules in the asymmetric unit. The refinement converged to R (all data) = 9.34% and wR2 (all data) = 17.61%. Full details of the data collection and refinement and tables of atomic coordinates, bond lengths and angles, and torsion angles have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (CCDC, 2032227).

sec.title: 3.4.3. X-ray crystal structure of 6
sec.p: Crystal was triclinic, space group P1, cell volume 1214.14(18) Å 3 and unit cell dimensions a = 9.6885(8) Å, b = 11.3308(9) Å and c = 12.2463(12) Å, and α = 75.692(8) ◦ , β = 69.897(9) ◦ and γ = 78.686(7) ◦ . There are two molecules in the asymmetric unit. The refinement converged to R (all data) = 8.74% and wR2 (all data) = 10.64%. Full details of the data collection and refinement and tables of atomic coordinates, bond lengths and angles, and torsion angles have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (CCDC, 2032184).

sec.title: 3.5. Conformational kinetics of 6 by analysis of NMR theoretical and experimental data
sec.p: Variable temperature NMR spectra of 6 were obtained at 22, 25, 30, 35, 40, 45, and 50 ◦ C (Figures S26-S30). Higher temperatures were not attempted to prevent a possible decomposition.

Conformational search, dihedral driver and molecular mechanics MM2 minimizations were done in Chem3D Ultra (PerkinElmer Inc.). Quantum mechanical DFT minimizations (Gibbs energy) and GIAO 1 HNMR spectra calculations were performed with Gaussian 16 W (Gaussian Inc.) using the APFD method (
) and a 6-31G (d) basis set. All DFT calculations included an IEFPCM solvation model of DMSO. All calculated conformational transition states are minimal energy saddle points. To compare to experimental data, calculated NMR chemical shifts were converted by linear regression, using the experimental methoxy group chemical shift as reference.

Conformer populations were calculated at 298 K from conformational Gibbs energies by using the Boltzmann distribution equation. Rate constants were calculated at 298 K from the calculated activation Gibbs energies using the Eyring equation.

sec.title: 3.6.1. Bacterial strains and testing conditions
sec.p:
Four reference strains and three multidrug-resistant (MDR) strains were used in this study. Gram-positive bacteria included
Staphylococcus aureus
ATCC 29213,
Enterococcus faecalis
ATCC 29212 and environmental isolates
S. aureus
66/1 (
), a methicillin-resistant isolate (MRSA), and
E. faecalis
B3/101 (
) a vancomycin-resistant (VRE) isolate. Gram-negative strains comprised
Escherichia coli
ATCC 25922,
Pseudomonas aeruginosa
ATCC 27853 and clinical isolate
E. coli
SA/2, an extended-spectrum β- lactamase producer (ESBL). Frozen stocks of all strains were grown in Mueller-Hinton agar (MH-BioKar Diagnostics, Allone, France ) at 37 ◦ C and, before each assay, were sub-cultured in MH agar and incubated overnight at 37 ◦ C in order to obtain fresh cultures.

Stock solutions of the compounds were prepared in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO- Alfa Aesar, Kandel, Germany ), kept at 20 ◦ C, and freshly diluted in the appropriate culture media before each assay. With the exception of 3 , 5 and 4 , 10 mg /mL stock solutions were prepared. For 3 and 4 , a 4 mg /mL stock solution was prepared, whereas for 5 a 2 mg /mL stock solution was prepared, as these compounds were less soluble in DMSO than the others. In all experiments, in-test concentrations of DMSO were kept below 1%, as recommended by the Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (
).

sec.title: 3.6.2. Antimicrobial susceptibility testing
sec.p:
The antimicrobial activity of the compounds was screened by the Kirby-Bauer method, as recommended by the
: 6 mm blank paper discs (Liofilchem, Roseto degli Abruzzi, TE, Italy ) were impregnated with 15 μg of each compound, and blank paper discs impregnated with DMSO were used as negative control. MH inoculated plates were incubated for 18–20 h at 37 ◦ C. The results were evaluated by measuring the inhibition halos.

sec.title: 3.6.3. Biofilm formation inhibition assay
4. Conclusions
sec.p:
Two undescribed viomellein derivatives, xanthoelegansin ( 6 ) and spiroxanthoelegansin ( 7 ) were isolated, together with previously reported naphthopyranone fungal pigments vioxanthin ( 3 ), xanthomegnin ( 4 ), viomellein ( 5 ), rubrosulphin ( 8a ), rubrosulphin diacetate ( 8b ), viopurpurin ( 8c ), and other specialised metabolites including clavatol ( 1 ), sitosteanone ( 2 ), ochratoxin A ( 9a ), ochratoxin A methyl ester ( 9b ), ochratoxin B ( 9c ) and ochratoxin β ( 10 ), from the marine-derived fungus
Aspergillus elegans
strain KUFA0015, which was obtained from the marine sponge
Monanchora unguiculata
. The structures and absolute configurations of the stereogenic carbons of 3 , 5 and 6 were confirmed by X-ray analysis. The presence of a 1,3-dioxepine ring in 6 and a spiropyran ring in 7 are unprecedented among the previously reported naphthopyranone fungal pigments. Moreover, the conformational change of the 1,3-dioxepine ring in 6 was interpreted by the observation of the 1 HNMR spectra in DMSO ‑d 6 at varying temperatures together with the calculated quantum mechanical theoretical data. The mechanisms of the formation of the 1,3-dioxepine ring in 6 and the spiropyran ring in 7 , from 5 , were proposed. Although 3 , 4, 5 and 9b displayed a halo of growth inhibition for all the Gram-positive strains, 3 is the most promising compound showing a potent activity against all Gram-positive reference and multidrug-resistant strains tested. Moreover, 3 , 4 , 5 and 9b were found to almost completely inhibit biofilm formation of
E. faecalis
and
S. aureus
reference strains at MIC and 2xMIC concentrations. Therefore, naphthopyranone fungal pigments can be considered as a group of specialised metabolites with high potential for further development as arsenal against multidrug-resistant bacteria.
